g.text: FIB-4 index serves as a noninvasive prognostic
, Rong Wang, MD, Xianjin Yang, MD
brosis index FIB-4 has been reported to be linked with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) prognosis, but the
results were not consistent. This study aimed to synthetically explore the relationship between FIB-4 and clinical outcomes of HCC.
A number of online databases were searched for relevant articles published before March 1, 2018. Hazard ratios (HRs)
dence intervals (95% CIs) were calculated to assess the prognostic value of the FIB-4 index in patients with HCC using
Eight articles (including 10 cohort studies) with 3485 HCC patients were
nally included for analysis. The pooled results
showed that FIB-4 index was signi
cantly associated with overall survival (OS) for patients with HCC (HR
.001). And HCC patients with higher FIB-4 score were at signi
cantly greater risk of recurrence 1.53 (95% CI: 1.29
.001). Subgroup analysis based on the treatment, stage and analysis type also con
rmed the prognostic values of the FIB-4 score
for OS and recurrence-free survival (RFS) in HCC.
FIB-4 index might be a useful predictive marker in patients with HCC.
FIB-4 index, hepatocellular carcinoma, meta-analysis, prognosis
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the third leading cause of
cancer-related death worldwide and over half of the new HCC
cases and deaths occurred in China.
the most commonly curative treatment in HCC patients. However,
their prognosis, especially the long-term survival rate remains
unsatisfactory because of the high frequency of tumor recur-
Thus, predicting the survival and recurrence for HCC
patients can help to guide their post-treatment management.
There are many risk factors for HCC, including viral infection
brosis degree, which are also closely related to HCC
FIB-4 index, a novel scoring system, can be
calculated by the following formula: age x AST/platelet count [x
It was previously used to assess the severity
brosis and considered to be a useful
Interestingly, some studies reported that the FIB-4
score was correlated with the prognosis of HCC in recent years,
and it could serve as a prognostic factor for HCC.
However, the prognostic value of the FIB-4 index in HCC remain
aim of this meta-analysis was to systematically evaluate the
relationship between the FIB-4 index and HCC patient outcomes
after treatments and provide a better understanding of the impact
of the FIB-4 index on HCC patient prognosis.
Due to our work is a meta-analysis of the published literature, the
ethical approval is not required. The following online databases
were searched for eligible articles: PubMed, Web of Science,
Cochrane Library, Embase, Wanfang Data, and China National
Knowledge Infrastructure (CNKI). The retrieval time was updated
as of March 1, 2018. The search terms were as follows: (FIB-4 OR
Fibrosis-4) AND (hepatocellular OR liver OR hepatic) AND
(carcinoma ORcancer ORneoplasmOR tumor). We also manually
reviewed the references in relevant studies for potential studies.
(1) an article explored the prognostic impact of FIB-4 index in
